THE
PRINCE ALBERT
YOUNG MEN'S LITERARY
AND
ATHLETIC CLUB.

Established November 16th, A.D. 1883, at
Prince Albert, in the Saskatchewan
District of the North West
Territories of Canada.

Printed by Spink & Haverty, Prince Albert Times Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.
THE PRINCE ALBERT YOUNG MEN'S HISTORICAL AND ATHLETIC CLUB.

TOWNSHIPS OF CANADA.
Details of the Young Men's Historical and Athletic Club.

Printed by Albert & Macdonald, Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.
THE
PRINCE ALBERT
YOUNG MENS LITERARY
AND
ATHLETIC CLUB.

CONSTITUTION AND BY-LAWS, ETC.

Established at Prince Albert, N.W.T., 16th November, A.D. 1883.
Officers of the Club.

President—Hon. L. Clarke, Chief Factor, H.B.C.

Vice-Presidents—Col. Sproat, Thos. Swanston, and Jas. Macarthur, Esqs.

Executive Committee—Messrs. Fitz. Cochrane, J. H. Knowles, Joseph D. Hanafin, W. R. Gunn, George Mills, Thomas A. Spink and Graham Nelson.

Treasurer—J. Hector Knowles.

Secretary—Fitzgerald Cochrane.
Constitution.

That this Association shall be called and known as the Prince Albert Young Mens Literary and Athletic Club.

That the objects of this Club are the establishment and maintenance of suitable rooms wherein the young men of Prince Albert can meet for mutual instruction and amusement, for the exercise of the mind as well as the body. "Mens sana in corpore sano," being our motto.

That in order to carry out the objects of this Club, suitable rooms shall be engaged for a gymnasium and for a reading room, and place for games, such as chess, draughts, dominoes, whist, etc.

That the officers of this Club shall consist of a President, one or more Vice-Presidents, a Secretary and Treasurer, and an Executive Committee, of seven members, whose duties are defined in the By-Laws.

That all contributors of the sum of $100 and upwards towards the funds of the Club shall be considered Life and Honorary members thereof.

That in addition to the above objects, the Club will encourage the holding of Penny Readings on certain evenings, the formation of a Glee or Musical Club, and the giving of occasional Concerts under the auspices of the Club, the delivery of short Lectures on Scientific and Literary subjects, the giving of prizes for snow-shoeing and skating races, exhibition of gymnastics and athletic sports, etc.
By-Laws.

1. That the officers of this Club shall consist of a President, one or more Vice-Presidents, a Secretary and Treasurer, who shall be elected at the annual meeting of the Club, which will be held on the first Tuesday of November in each year, by ballot.

2. That this Club shall be under the control and management of an Executive Committee of seven, who shall be elected by ballot at the annual meeting of the Club, and whose duty it shall be to look after the general management of the affairs of the Club, financial and directory, to supervise the management of the rooms, to enforce order and observance of the By-Laws, to direct the Janitor in the discharge of his duties, and generally to exercise a supervision over the affairs of the Club. The Executive Committee (whilst the whole, or a majority of its members will retain control over the whole Club) may subdivide its duties by detailing to each member, by rotation for one week, the duty of taking charge of the rooms, and seeing that the Janitor attends to his duties, and that the rooms are run according to the By-Laws. When any vacancies occur in the Executive Committee during the year from resignation, removal or other cause, such vacancies may be filled up by the remaining portion of the Committee electing a member or members by ballot to serve the remainder of the year.

3. That the Secretary and Treasurer shall perform the duties usually assigned to those offices.
4. That each member of this Club shall pay the sum of one dollar per month, towards the support of the Club, such sum to be payable on the first day of every month; and also the sum of fifty cents entrance fee, payable in advance.

5. That applicants for membership shall be duly proposed by some member of the Club, who shall hand in the name to the Executive Committee, and be responsible for the entrance fee and first month's subscription.

6. That all members on joining the Club shall sign the Constitution and By-Laws and pay one month's subscription and the entrance fee in advance.

7. That the Club rooms shall be open from 10 o'clock in the morning until 11 o'clock at night, every day, Sunday excepted.

8. That a janitor or caretaker be appointed by the Executive Committee, whose duty it shall be to open the rooms and keep them open during the hours named; to light the fires, at a sufficiently early hour to have the rooms comfortable at the hour of opening; to look after the sawing and splitting of the wood and to see that there is always a sufficient supply on hand; to look after the fuel and lights, and to see that the lights and fires are extinguished and the rooms closed at the hour named; to see that the rooms are kept clean and neat; that the newspapers, magazines, etc., are kept in good order; that all games and tables on which they are played be kept in good order; to report any infringements of the By-Laws to the
Executive Committee and generally to obey the directions of the Executive Committee.

9. No gambling, profane or indecent language, or loud talking calculated to disturb the members, or unruly conduct of any kind, shall be allowed in the rooms under a penalty for the first offence of a fine of fifty cents; for the second offence suspension from the rooms for one week; and for the third offence expulsion from the Club. No discussions on religious or political subjects will be allowed in the rooms under a penalty of a fine of fifty cents for each offence.

10. No periodicals, books or papers shall be taken out of the rooms on any pretext whatever.

11. No drinking of intoxicants of any kind shall be allowed in the Club rooms under a penalty of one dollar for the first offence and expulsion from the Club for the second.

12. The Executive Committee or a majority of them shall have power to dismiss the Janitor for inattention to his duties, or other sufficient cause, and to appoint another in his place.

13. Any member of the Club may have the privilege of introducing a friend (being a non-resident) for a period not exceeding two weeks.

14. No alteration or amendments of these By-Laws shall be made except at a special meeting of the Club, called for that purpose after one month's notice.
By-Laws.

FOR THE REGULATION OF THE GYMNASIUM.

The properties of the Gymnasium are vested in and belong to the Club.

No member of the Club shall be allowed to take away from the Club Rooms any of the fittings or furniture of the Gymnasium under any pretext whatever.

Any damage wilfully done to any of the fittings or properties of the Gymnasium must be made good and paid for by the party committing it.

Every member in the absence of a member of the Executive Committee is expected to use his utmost to maintain good conduct and order and to preserve the properties of the Club, and to see that the By-laws and Rules are observed.
List of Members.

Hon. L. Clarke, W. R. Gunn, Jos. Knowles, J. D. Maveety, A. Sproat, Wm. Barker, Graham Nelson, J. H. Wilmot, R. Middleton, John Flett, W. Goodfellow, D. J. Gunn, Wm. R. Dobbie, Fitz. Cochrane, T. A.
